author: NightCabbage
title: My first Technic
review:
Haha, this was my very first Technic set ever! :)

Pretty simple design - rotate the handle, and the blades spin.
It was cool that the back blade spins, too.

I didn't like the alternate model much, though.

I later got the motor (8720) to put in it - worked quite well.

author: Victor_c3
title: Nothing special, but it was a good set for parts
review:
I received this set for christmas as a present from my little brother. I think I made the models in the instructions once each, then I threw the parts into my parts mix. Overall, it wasn't that special of a set, but did use the grey lift-arm pieces in a lot of my MOCs. Actually, I can't even recall that I liked the models that I made with this set.

 

To be consistant with my general opinion of any set released circa 1990s and earlier, if you are looking for a set that you can play with, skip over it. Save it this one for the collectors. You'll get a lot more functionality, robustness, and useful parts out of a model released within the last decade than you will with this one.

author: Crazy_Chris
title: Good-looking small helicopter
review:
The set:

Released in 1990, this set seems to be a "partner" set for 8832. It uses the same color scheme (black parts, red seat, yellow details), it's scale is similar, box size and prices were identical.

 

The parts:

We get some black technic bricks and standard plates, and no less than 14 liftarms 1x4, which still new and interesting parts in 1990.

 

The model:

It looks simple-designed, but it looks like a helicopter. Main rotor and tail rotor can be driven manually, which is the only technical feature of this model.

The red seat allows to put a technicfig into the cockpit. But where to put it's legs ?

 

B-model:

Quite interesting: The B-model is a small plane which adjustable wings.

 

Summary:

This set is not a must-have. But it looks nice, the parts are useful. All in all, you can't go too wrong with it.
